thread.title: US soccer has no escape from Klinsmann’s pervasive failure
thread.title_full: US soccer has no escape from Klinsmann’s pervasive failure | New York Post

author: Mark Cannizzaro
title: US soccer has no escape from Klinsmann’s pervasive failure
text:
What should have been a celebration of the US Men’s National Soccer Team on Tuesday night at Red Bull Arena instead is an up-close look at a program in turmoil with questions about the effectiveness of high-profile coach Jurgen Klinsmann hovering over his head like a red card.
Klinsmann’s US side, playing Costa Rica in a friendly match, is three nights removed from an alarming loss to archrival Mexico in the CONCACAF Cup in Southern California, falling short of a berth into the 2017 Confederations Cup, considered to be a critical step in the team’s world advancement.
Considering the stakes, the stagnant state of the program and the one-sidedness of the match, an argument can be made rather easily that the loss to Mexico was the worst of the Klinsmann era.
The match, lopsided far beyond the 3-2 final score in overtime with the US on its heels in a defensive mode nearly the entire match, provided 117 minutes of footage on how little the former German national star has done to advance US soccer since he was hired in 2011.
Mexico celebrates a goal against the US. Photo: AP For those who are convinced this Klinsmann experiment has timed out and change must be made, here’s the problem: He’s signed through 2018, which means through the next World Cup.
And Klinsmann has too much power. When he signed a four-year extension after the last World Cup, Klinsmann also became the Technical Director for US Soccer, which has far-reaching implications with regard to the growth of the sport at the highest level in America.
Not only is the national team struggling, but the US is in danger of not qualifying for the 2016 Olympic Games, which would be inexcusable.
Here’s a recent sample of the state of US Soccer under Klinsmann’s watch:
• Last Tuesday, the U-20 national team lost 8-1 to Germany in Klinsmann’s hometown of Stuttgart.
• On Saturday afternoon, the U-23 national team, coached by Austrian Andi Herzog and German assistant Matthias Hamann (both hand-picked by Klinsmann), was dominated by Honduras 2-0 in its effort to qualify for the Olympics.
• Later Saturday, Klinsmann’s national team was manhandled by Mexico.
Jurgen Klinsmann claims Fabian Johnson (right) faked an injury to get out of the game. Photo: Getty Images Not a good week. More importantly, a week indicative of how US soccer is running in place with Klinsmann in charge — in no better a place than it was under the watch of his predecessors, Bob Bradley and Bruce Arena.
Before the loss to Mexico, Klinsmann said “winning this CONCACAF Cup is really crucial.”
The loss to Mexico came after the US managed a pedestrian fourth-place finish on home soil at the Gold Cup, a tournament Klinsmann had called “very, very important to us’’ before his team was outshot, 75-25, by Honduras, Panama and Haiti.
The roster Klinsmann is bringing to Tuesday night’s friendly against Costa Rica was radically altered following the loss to Mexico, with eight players released from team duties and five others called up.
One of eight players released was right back Fabian Johnson, who Klinsmann claimed faked an injury in overtime of the Mexico match and asked to be subbed off the field.
“I had a very severe word with Fabian Johnson, and I sent him home today,” Klinsmann said Monday. “He can rethink his approach about his team.’’
There are many who believe Klinsmann needs to rethink his approach to building US Soccer.
“Everybody can express his opinion, and not everyone likes you,’’ Klinsmann said before Tuesday’s match. “That’s totally fine. I’m not here to be liked. I’m trying to do a good job, and I’m privileged to have that role and represent the US soccer program. I do my best, to my capabilities, and leave the judgment out there for you guys and for people who want to express themselves.”
